natural problem: Find the product of $10101_2$ and $101_2$. Express your answer in base $2$.
natural solution: Carry out the multiplication as you would with base $10$. There is no need to carry during the multiplication with base $2$. $$\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} &&&&1&0&1&0&1_2\\ &&&&&\times&1&0&1_2\\ \cline{2-9} &&&_1&1^{\text{ }}&0^1&1^{\text{ }}&0^{\text{ }}&1^{\text{ }}_2\\ &+&1^{\text{ }}&0^{\text{ }}&1&0_{\text{ }}&1&0&0_2\\ \cline{2-9} &&1&1&0&1&0&0&1_2\\ \end{array}$$Add it up for a final answer of $\boxed{1101001_2}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = bin_of_nat 21"
and h1 : "b = bin_of_nat 5"
shows  "a * b = bin_of_nat 105"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the product of $10101_2$ and $101_2$. Express your answer in base $2$. The final Answer is 1101001_2
 ### Proof
 Carry out the multiplication as you would with base $10$. There is no need to carry during the multiplication with base $2$. $$\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} &&&&1&0&1&0&1_2\\ &&&&&\times&1&0&1_2\\ \cline{2-9} &&&_1&1^{\text{ }}&0^1&1^{\text{ }}&0^{\text{ }}&1^{\text{ }}_2\\ &+&1^{\text{ }}&0^{\text{ }}&1&0_{\text{ }}&1&0&0_2\\ \cline{2-9} &&1&1&0&1&0&0&1_2\\ \end{array}$$Add it up for a final answer of $\boxed{1101001_2}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = bin_of_nat 21"
and h1 : "b = bin_of_nat 5"
shows  "a * b = bin_of_nat 105"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: What is the product of the numbers 21 and 5 when both are converted to binary and then multiplied? The final answer is the binary representation of 105.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = nat (bin_of BL [True,False,True,False,True])"
and h1 : "b = nat (bin_of BL [True,False,True])"
shows  "a * b = nat (bin_of BL [True,True,False,True,False,False,True])"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the product of $10101_2$ and $101_2$. Express your answer in base $2$. The final Answer is 1101001_2
 ### Proof
 Carry out the multiplication as you would with base $10$. There is no need to carry during the multiplication with base $2$. $$\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} &&&&1&0&1&0&1_2\\ &&&&&\times&1&0&1_2\\ \cline{2-9} &&&_1&1^{\text{ }}&0^1&1^{\text{ }}&0^{\text{ }}&1^{\text{ }}_2\\ &+&1^{\text{ }}&0^{\text{ }}&1&0_{\text{ }}&1&0&0_2\\ \cline{2-9} &&1&1&0&1&0&0&1_2\\ \end{array}$$Add it up for a final answer of $\boxed{1101001_2}$.
 *)

fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = nat (bin_of BL [True,False,True,False,True])"
and h1 : "b = nat (bin_of BL [True,False,True])"
shows  "a * b = nat (bin_of BL [True,True,False,True,False,False,True])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Multiply the binary number 10101 (21 in decimal) by the binary number 101 (5 in decimal). What is the result? The final answer is 1110101 (165 in decimal).

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 21"
and h1 : "b = 5"
shows  "a * b = 105" (* 1101001 in base 2 is 105 in base 10 *)
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the product of $10101_2$ and $101_2$. Express your answer in base $2$. The final Answer is 1101001_2
 ### Proof
 Carry out the multiplication as you would with base $10$. There is no need to carry during the multiplication with base $2$. $$\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} &&&&1&0&1&0&1_2\\ &&&&&\times&1&0&1_2\\ \cline{2-9} &&&_1&1^{\text{ }}&0^1&1^{\text{ }}&0^{\text{ }}&1^{\text{ }}_2\\ &+&1^{\text{ }}&0^{\text{ }}&1&0_{\text{ }}&1&0&0_2\\ \cline{2-9} &&1&1&0&1&0&0&1_2\\ \end{array}$$Add it up for a final answer of $\boxed{1101001_2}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 21"
and h1 : "b = 5"
shows  "a * b = 105" (* 1101001 in base 2 is 105 in base 10 *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: What is the product of 21 and 5? The final answer is 105.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: int
assumes h0 : "a = bin_of_int 21"
and h1 : "b = bin_of_int 5"
shows  "a * b = bin_of_int 105" (* equivalent to 1101001 in base 2 *)
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the product of $10101_2$ and $101_2$. Express your answer in base $2$. The final Answer is 1101001_2
 ### Proof
 Carry out the multiplication as you would with base $10$. There is no need to carry during the multiplication with base $2$. $$\begin{array}{c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} &&&&1&0&1&0&1_2\\ &&&&&\times&1&0&1_2\\ \cline{2-9} &&&_1&1^{\text{ }}&0^1&1^{\text{ }}&0^{\text{ }}&1^{\text{ }}_2\\ &+&1^{\text{ }}&0^{\text{ }}&1&0_{\text{ }}&1&0&0_2\\ \cline{2-9} &&1&1&0&1&0&0&1_2\\ \end{array}$$Add it up for a final answer of $\boxed{1101001_2}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: int
assumes h0 : "a = bin_of_int 21"
and h1 : "b = bin_of_int 5"
shows  "a * b = bin_of_int 105" (* equivalent to 1101001 in base 2 *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Multiply the binary representations of the numbers 21 and 5. The final answer is the binary representation of 105.
